name: Ada Lovelace
contribution: Laid the foundation for computing by designing an algorithm for Charles Babbage’s Analytical Engine.

name: Edith Clarke
contribution: The first female electrical engineer and the first woman to professionally work as an electrical engineer in the U.S.

name: Grace Hopper
contribution: Developed the first compiler and contributed to the COBOL programming language.
category: World War II & the 1940s – Women Code Breakers & Programmers

name: Kay McNulty
contribution: Original programmer of the ENIAC, one of the first general-purpose computers.
category: World War II & the 1940s – Women Code Breakers & Programmers

name: Betty Jennings
contribution: Original programmer of the ENIAC, one of the first general-purpose computers.
category: World War II & the 1940s – Women Code Breakers & Programmers

name: Betty Snyder
contribution: Original programmer of the ENIAC, one of the first general-purpose computers.
category: World War II & the 1940s – Women Code Breakers & Programmers

name: Marlyn Meltzer
contribution: Original programmer of the ENIAC, one of the first general-purpose computers.
category: World War II & the 1940s – Women Code Breakers & Programmers

name: Fran Bilas
contribution: Original programmer of the ENIAC, one of the first general-purpose computers.
category: World War II & the 1940s – Women Code Breakers & Programmers

name: Ruth Lichterman
contribution: Original programmer of the ENIAC, one of the first general-purpose computers.
category: World War II & the 1940s – Women Code Breakers & Programmers

name: Joan Clarke
contribution: A British cryptanalyst who worked with Alan Turing at Bletchley Park to break the German Enigma code.
category: World War II & the 1940s – Women Code Breakers & Programmers

name: Mary Allen Wilkes
contribution: Developed the first personal computer operating system.

name: Margaret Hamilton
contribution: Led the software development team for NASA’s Apollo space program and coined the term 'software engineering.'

name: Katherine Johnson
contribution: A NASA mathematician who calculated flight trajectories for the Apollo 11 moon landing.

name: Evelyn Boyd Granville
contribution: One of the first African American women to earn a Ph.D. in mathematics and worked on space programs.

name: Radia Perlman
contribution: Known as the 'Mother of the Internet' for her work on network protocols, including Spanning Tree Protocol (STP).

name: Anita Borg
contribution: A strong advocate for women in computing and founder of the Institute for Women and Technology.

name: Shafi Goldwasser
contribution: A pioneer in cryptography and computer security.

name: Susan Wojcicki
contribution: Former CEO of YouTube and an early advocate for Google’s AdSense.

name: Sheryl Sandberg
contribution: Former COO of Meta (Facebook) and author of Lean In.

name: Fei-Fei Li
contribution: A leading AI researcher and advocate for ethical AI.

name: Kimberly Bryant
contribution: Founder of Black Girls Code, working to empower young Black girls in tech.
